Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Do you have an idea if there is a characterization of the affine schemes which are the set of zeroes of a polynomial?

This is a slightly strange question because an affine scheme is not a set. Also, people are much more interested in collections of polynomials, not a single polynomial. But maybe you are trying to ask a hard question.

Say we have a field kkk and a finite collection of polynomials P1,…,Pm∈k[x1,…,xn]P_1, \dots, P_m \in k[x_1, \dots, x_n]P1​,…,Pm​∈k[x1​,…,xn​]. We can do two different things.

First, we can look at the set X⊆knX \subseteq k^nX⊆kn where all these polynomials vanish. This sort of set is called an algebraic set. Without loss of generality we can take this collection to be finite, say P1,…,PmP_1, \dots, P_mP1​,…,Pm​.

Second, we can form the commutative ring k[x1,…,xn]/Jk[x_1, \dots, x_n]/Jk[x1​,…,xn​]/J where JJJ is the ideal generated by P1,…,PmP_1, \dots, P_mP1​,…,Pm​. Since affine schemes correspond to commutative rings, this is an affine scheme.

So, there are two questions we could ask here:

1) which subsets of knk^nkn are algebraic sets?

2) which affine schemes are of the form k[x1,…,xn]/Jk[x_1, \dots, x_n]/Jk[x1​,…,xn​]/J where JJJ is the ideal generated by P1,…,PmP_1, \dots, P_mP1​,…,Pm​?

Question 2) has an easy answer: they are just the affine schemes whose corresponding commutative rings are finitely presented kkk-algebras. And interestingly, these are the same as finitely generated kkk-algebras.

From what I said you might guess that algebraic sets are "the same" as finitely generated kkk-algebras. But no: nonisomorphic finitely generated kkk-algebras can give isomorphic algebraic sets. It's good (and not terribly hard) to think of an example.

Suppose we're in C3\mathbb{C}^3C3 and we form the subset

{(x,y,z)∈C3:  x=y=0} \{(x,y,z) \in \mathbb{C}^3 : \; x = y = 0 \} {(x,y,z)∈C3:x=y=0}

This is the zero set of a pair of polynomials. Can you can express it as the set of zeros of a single polynomial? Or, conversely, can you prove it's impossible?

For any sort of gadget with operations obeying equations we can talk about a "presentation" in terms of generators and relations. Examples include monoids, groups, rings, vector spaces, and what I'm talking about now: associative unital algebras over a field. We say a gadget is "finitely presented" if it has a presentation with finitely many generators and finitely many relations.
However, to be really accurate I should have used the term "finitely presentable".

Okay, the interesting thing about R3\mathbb{R}^3R3 is that the two equations

x=0,y=0x = 0, \qquad y = 0x=0,y=0

are equivalent to just one equation:

x2+y2=0 x^2 + y^2 = 0 x2+y2=0

In general, we can use this trick to take any finite number of polynomial equations in nnn real variables and write them as just one equation!

But this relies on the fact that in R\mathbb{R}R we have

a1=a2=⋯=0  ⟺  a12+a22+⋯+an2=0 a_1 = a_2 = \cdots = 0 \iff a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \cdots + a_n^2 = 0 a1​=a2​=⋯=0⟺a12​+a22​+⋯+an2​=0

In general, we say a field is formally real if

a1=a2=⋯=0  ⟺  a12+a22+⋯+an2=0 a_1 = a_2 = \cdots = 0 \iff a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \cdots + a_n^2 = 0 a1​=a2​=⋯=0⟺a12​+a22​+⋯+an2​=0

and examples include Q,R\mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{R}Q,R, the algebraic real numbers, the hyperreals, etc.
Formally real fields have lots of nice properties and many nice equivalent definitions (click the link).
But formally real fields are never algebraically complete, since x2=−1x^2 = -1x2=−1 obviously can't have a solution in a formally real field.
(Here I'm using "obviously" to mean "think about it - I bet you can see why, since it follows pretty quickly from the definition.)

If I were an actual algebraic geometer I could probably give several proofs, but since I'm just a beginner I'll point you to

  • Wikipedia, Dimension theory (algebra).

which outlines some of the technology needed to prove that you can't describe

{(x,y,z)∈C3:  x=y=0} \{(x,y,z) \in \mathbb{C}^3 : \; x = y = 0 \} {(x,y,z)∈C3:x=y=0}

with fewer than two polynomial equations.

The rough idea is that this line

{(x,y,z)∈C3:  x=y=0} \{(x,y,z) \in \mathbb{C}^3 : \; x = y = 0 \} {(x,y,z)∈C3:x=y=0}

has (complex) dimension 1, and it's sitting a space of complex dimension 3, so it takes 3-1 = 2 equations to describe it, at least locally. But the hard part is defining "dimension" and using it to prove this sort of fact.

Here's a low-tech, hands-on proof that the single point (0,0)∈C2(0,0) \in \mathbb{C}^2(0,0)∈C2 cannot be the zero set of a single polynomial P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y).
Suppose it was. Write PPP as a polynomial in yyy: P(x,y)=P0(x)+P1(x)y+P2(x)y2+⋯+Pn(x)ynP(x,y) = P_0(x) + P_1(x)y + P_2(x)y^2 + \cdots + P_n(x)y^nP(x,y)=P0​(x)+P1​(x)y+P2​(x)y2+⋯+Pn​(x)yn.

We know that for fixed x=a≠0x = a \ne 0x=a=0, the polynomial P(a,y)∈C[y]P(a,y) \in \mathbb{C}[y]P(a,y)∈C[y] has no roots. On the other hand, C\mathbb{C}C is algebraically closed so the only way this can happen is if P(a,y)P(a,y)P(a,y) is a nonzero constant polynomial: i.e. P0(a)≠0P_0(a) \ne 0P0​(a)=0, while Pi(a)=0P_i(a) = 0Pi​(a)=0 for i>0i > 0i>0.

Now consider a fixed i>0i > 0i>0. We know that for every a≠0a \ne 0a=0, we're supposed to have Pi(a)=0P_i(a) = 0Pi​(a)=0. Since C\mathbb{C}C is infinite, this can happen only if PiP_iPi​ is the zero polynomial.

That means our original polynomial must have been of the form P(x,y)=P0(x)P(x,y) = P_0(x)P(x,y)=P0​(x). But then, it is not possible that (0,0)(0,0)(0,0) is the only root of PPP. (The points (0,b)(0, b)(0,b) for b≠0b \ne 0b=0 would have to be roots also.)
